node.title: Stephen Karpiak, Pathbreaking H.I.V. Researcher, Dies at 74
node.alt: Stephen Karpiak studied the quality of life and the mental health of older people with H.I.V. In 2012 he attended a panel in Washington on aging with the virus alongside Carolyn Massey, who had H.I.V.
node.description: His work helped change people’s attitude toward older people living with the virus that causes AIDS.
node.content: ["Stephen Karpiak, whose research into the lives of New Yorkers aging with H.I.V. revealed a scarcity of support networks and high rates of depression, leading to changes in the care of older people living with the virus, died on Oct. 16 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 74. ", "His brother, Michael, said the cause was kidney damage that resulted from an infection.", "AIDS had a devastating impact on gay men in the 1980s, especially in New York. The advent of antiretroviral drugs in the 1990s marked the beginning of a hopeful shift, and a decade later, after an era of despair, gay life reclaimed its vibrancy in the city. But Dr. Karpiak at the time was starting to conduct research about older adults living with H.I.V. and he was troubled by what he was learning.", "The landmark study launched by Dr. Karpiak interviewed 1,000 New Yorkers over 50 about their quality of life and mental health; it eventually also included San Francisco, Oakland and Chicago. The data was stark.", "Dr. Karpiak learned that his subjects struggled with fragile support networks and inadequate health care, and that 70 percent of those infected by H.I.V. lived alone; this social isolation resulted in substantially higher rates of depression. His study, \u201cResearch on Older Adults With H.I.V.,\u201d was published in 2006, and he dedicated the rest of his career to building on it.", "\u201cThere was a core message that you would detect in the focus group data: \u2018You abandoned us,\u2019\u201d Dr. Karpiak said in a 2020 interview. \u201cThey say, \u2018Gee, you saved our lives, but at what cost? You gave us extended life, but at the cost of impoverishment, continued rejection, ageism, and stigma.\u2019\u201d", "\u201cWe gave them a pill,\u201d he added, \u201cthen said goodbye to them.\u201d", "Dr. Karpiak, who witnessed the AIDS crisis as a gay man in New York in the 1980s, became an impassioned advocate for those aging with the disease and railed against ageism.", "\u201cThey encounter programs where the emphasis on prevention of H.I.V. in high-risk youth and young-adult populations often dominates,\u201d he wrote in a 2019 article for Positively Aware magazine. \u201cWe live in a society where youth receive the highest premium. Aging is seen as a disease rather than an inevitable process of living.\u201d", "Dr. Karpiak championed his cause at the AIDS Community Research Initiative of America, where he worked as a lead researcher for years.", "He built caregiving networks for older people with H.I.V., trained health care providers in treatment strategies and became a skilled fund-raiser who dealt with supporters like Donna Karan and Calvin Klein. His research was also backed by large grants from pharmaceutical giants like Gilead. \u200b\u200b", "Dr. Karpiak sought to reach his research subjects directly. As executive director of the Pride Senior Network, which he joined in 1999, he ran and edited The Networker, a free quarterly newspaper aimed at older gay New Yorkers that was distributed in bars and doctors\u2019 offices. Its inaugural issue, in 2000, featured a manifesto about age discrimination by the novelist Patricia Nell Warren.", "In 2010, he participated in a conference on H.I.V. and aging at the White House, and he also helped start National H.I.V./AIDS and Aging Awareness Day.", "\u201cAs Stephen grew older as a gay man himself, because he was a scientist, he couldn\u2019t help but notice disparities around him,\u201d said Tonya Taylor, an assistant professor at SUNY Downstate Health Sciences University in Brooklyn who was mentored by Dr. Karpiak, and studies women aging with H.I.V. \u201cHe gave visibility to this topic and brought it out from the darkness.\u201d", "Stephen Edward Karpiak Jr. was born on Aug, 13, 1947, in Hartford, Conn. His father was a fire captain. His mother, Olga (Yanenko) Karpiak, was a judicial secretary.", "He graduated from the College of the Holy Cross with a degree in psychology in 1969 and earned his doctorate in experimental psychology at Fordham University in 1972. He joined Columbia University\u2019s medical school as a researcher studying seizures and behavioral disorders.", "In his 30s, Dr. Karpiak lived in the West Village and was immersed in the city\u2019s gay nightlife. He partied until dawn at clubs like the Saint and the leather bar Ramrod, and he fell in love with a schoolteacher, who became his partner. When the AIDS crisis began, he started receiving messages on his answering machine from friends desperately seeking his medical advice. He also began attending funerals constantly.", "\u201cLosing all those people was never far from his mind,\u201d said his brother, who is his only immediate survivor. \u201cAnd it tied deeply into his personal life. He lost his lover, who was his soul mate.\u201d", "His partner\u2019s death stirred something in him.", "\u201cWhen he finally saw those who survived, he saw they weren\u2019t surviving well,\u201d he added. \u201cSo Stephen thought, \u2018How can I do something about this?\u2019 He couldn\u2019t do anything when it was happening in the 1980s, but then he got his chance.\u201d", "Dr. Karpiak left Columbia University in the mid-1990s and moved to Phoenix to run a clinic for people living with H.I.V. He also managed an agency there that provided housing for homeless men living with the virus.", "Dr. Karpiak returned to New York in 1999 to lead the Pride Senior Network. One day at a health fair he gave out a simple questionnaire that asked: If you are older and were to suddenly fall ill, do you have someone who would care for you? After studying the responses, he undertook his research.", "Dr. Karpiak joined the faculty of New York University\u2019s College of Nursing in his 60s and later worked for G.M.H.C. (formerly Gay Men\u2019s Health Crisis), where he founded its National Resource Center on H.I.V. and Aging.", "When the coronavirus pandemic gripped New York, Dr. Karpiak grew concerned about how older people living with H.I.V. would be affected by lockdown. Sequestered in his Hell\u2019s Kitchen apartment, he took part in web conferences with medical experts to address the topic. He always encouraged his research subjects to tune in, so they could hear that someone was looking out for them.", "\u201cThe Covid-19 pandemic showed us that we are an ageist society,\u201d Dr. Karpiak said in 2020. \u201cWe hear misinformation constantly: \u2018This virus only affects old people,\u2019 so most people, \u2018don\u2019t need to worry about it so much.\u2019\u201d", "\u201cI have heard many older adults say, \u2018The worst thing in the world is to feel abandoned,\u2019\u201d he continued. \u201cEven more unsettling is hearing from them, \u2018There is something worse than AIDS, like loneliness.\u2019\u201d"]
